caption.center: Anthony Lamar ABERNATHY v. STATE of Arkansas

opinion.syllabus: APPEAL ERROR — MOTION TO COMPLETE RECORD — GRANTED. — Where the State had obtained numerous extensions to file its brief and requested another, offering no explanation for its delay in requesting that the record be made complete, the supreme court granted the motion because appellant had voiced no objection to the State's motion to complete the record; the court also stayed brief time until thirty days after completion of the record but admonished the State that no further extensions would be approved.
opinion.posture: Motions to Complete the Record and to Stay Brief Time; granted.
opinion.attorneys:
Anthony Lamar Abernathy, no response.
Winston Bryant, Att'y Gen., by: Sandy Moll, Asst. Att'y Gen., for appellee.
opinion.opinion_text:
The state moves to complete the record on appeal, requesting the opening statement and closing argument be included. The state has had numerous extensions to file its brief — one on December 4, 1995, one on December 11, 1995, and another on January 10, 1996. To grant the state's present motion will require another extension.
The state offers no explanation for its delay in requesting the record be made complete, and we discern none, since appellant's notice of appeal filed on March 20, 1995 clearly excluded opening statements and closing arguments. The necessity for additional record should have been evident either before or at the time appellant filed his brief on October 30, 1995.
[1] Because appellant is said to voice no objection to the state's motion, we grant it. We also stay brief time until thirty days after the record is completed, but we admonish the statePage 564 that no further extensions will be approved.
